title: OECD Selects Australia's Cormann as Next Secretary-General
summary: Former Australian finance minister lists global economic recovery, climate change action as priorities for think tank. SYDNEY-The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development chose former Australian finance minister Mathias Cormann to be its next secretary-general, as it seeks to shape the global economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Schumer and Gillibrand Call for Cuomo to Resign
summary: New York governor has said he won't resign, vowing to continue to lead the state. ALBANY, N.Y.-Sens. Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand joined 16 Democratic members of the state's House delegation in calling for Gov. Andrew Cuomo to step down amid mounting accusations of sexual harassment and investigations into his handling of Covid-19 deaths in nursing homes.

title: The Semiconductor Shortage
summary: Do we really want government getting into the chip business?. A global computer chip shortage has constrained worldwide production of goods from iPhones to Sony PlayStations to Ford trucks. President Biden has called for $37 billion from Congress to boost U.S. semiconductor manufacturing, but government industrial policy isn't needed to correct this supply-demand problem.

title: Braun for the States
summary: A GOP Senator resists the Democratic ban on state tax cuts.. The Democratic sneak attack on states that run sound fiscal policies is finding a note of resistance. Indiana Senator Mike Braun read our editorial this week and has introduced legislation that would remove the language that Democrats put into their $1.9 trillion spending bill at the last minute to ban state tax cuts through 2024.

title: A Police Reform Crossroads
summary: Democrats can choose to compromise or continue dividing the country.. A crime wave continues to roil American cities, but Democrats' outlook is the same as last summer: Their priority is to restrict policing rather than strengthen it. Last week the House moved on that goal by passing a bill that would leave officers less room to maintain public order. Republicans are countering with a compromise that preserves the worthy parts of the plan, and Speaker Nancy Pelosi's willingness to reach a deal will reveal her party's real interest in public safety.

title: Ford Nominates Two Ford Family Heirs to Its Board
summary: Great-great-grandchildren of founder Henry Ford would deepen family's involvement in auto maker's corporate governance. Ford Motor Co. has nominated a pair of fifth-generation descendants of founder Henry Ford to its board, deepening the family's involvement in the auto maker's corporate governance.

title: Submission Is on Exhibit at the Indianapolis Museum of Art
summary: A progressive cultural institution issues a groveling mea culpa for a poorly worded job posting.. Indianapolis

title: Dr. Seuss, Meet the Sanitized Sleuths Known as the Hardy Boys
summary: The detective novels got a rewrite in 1959. Was it a needed scrubbing or a sign of cancel culture?. The recent decision by the estate of Theodor "Dr. Seuss" Geisel to pull six of his books because of crude stereotypical portrayals has exploded in the news. Some claim that the action represents the worst of cancel culture, while others praise the decision because they believe the depictions can promote racial insensitivity.

title: Cuomo and the Covid Death Count
summary: Nursing-home fatalities are not well-reported, but which coronavirus-related deaths are?. New York, Pennsylvania, Michigan and New Jersey erred gravely by directing nursing homes to receive recovering Covid patients, but the bigger mistake was sending caregivers home rather than quarantining them between shifts. The workers-not the infected patients from hospitals-were the real (unwitting) channel for thousands of deaths thanks to Covid's nasty capacity for asymptomatic spread.

title: A Grammys Playlist: What Eight Songs Tell Us About Music's Annual Awards Night
summary: What songs by artists in top categories tell us about pop music and what to expect from music's annual award night. The Grammy Awards will look different this year-and it's not just because Covid-19 means some pre-taped performances. There's a new host, comedian Trevor Noah; a new executive producer, Ben Winston, who helms the show after his predecessor Ken Ehrlich's four-decade run; and-in a salute to the struggling concert industry, music-venue staffers will present awards.

title: Why College Wait Lists Will Be So Long This Year
summary: The pandemic has upended the methods admissions officers use to predict how many students will enroll. College wait lists have been bloated for years, used by colleges as a cushion along with binding early-decision programs, to ensure a complete class without sacrificing selectivity. But this year schools are expecting to turn to them as early as next month and pluck students well into late summer.

title: Google Says Microsoft's Stance on News Is Effort to Distract From Hack
summary: Two giants with a history of sparring trade shots over tech's impact on news industry. A long-simmering feud between tech giants reignited on Friday, with Microsoft Corp.'s president lashing out at Google and the search juggernaut's top lawyer firing back.

title: Biden Meets World Leaders in Quest for More Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: Leaders of U.S., Japan, Australia, India-known as the Quad-pledge to produce 1 billion doses by end of 2022, as part of broad effort to confront China. WASHINGTON-President Biden and leaders of Japan, India and Australia agreed in a virtual meeting Friday to collaborate on ways to sharply ramp up global coronavirus vaccine production as part of a broader effort to work together to confront China.

title: Beeple's $69 Million NFT Art Sold to Founder of Crypto Fund Metapurse
summary: NFTs are all the rage, but a Singapore-based investor says Beeple is now the star of his fund's nearly $120 million tokenized collection. Christie's said that a cryptocurrency investor based in Singapore called Metakovan won Beeple's $69 million digital collage at auction-a sale that smashed records in markets for both art and nonfungible tokens, or NFTs.

title: Theranos Founder Elizabeth Holmes Is Pregnant, Likely Delaying Trial
summary: She is due to give birth in July, when her trial on charges of fraud was scheduled to begin. Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes's criminal trial is almost certainly headed for another delay after her lawyers and prosecutors revealed in a Friday court filing that she is pregnant and due to give birth in July.

title: Value Investors Finally Have Reason to Celebrate-for Now
summary: Portfolio managers are snapping up shares of cyclical firms like banks and energy companies. Value stocks are beating growth stocks by the widest margin in two decades, the latest sign that investors expect the next year to bring a powerful economic rebound.

title: Dow Ends Best Week Since November
summary: Technology shares decline, the but Dow and S&P 500 rise to new peaks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose for the sixth consecutive session and set a record, boosted by signs that the domestic economy is revving up.

title: Private Made Public
summary: Today's readers of E.M. Delafield's 1930 'Diary of a Provincial Lady' may find more in common with the titular character than they expect. Stuck inside during the pandemic, many have begun keeping a journal, viewing the activity as a means of self-expression and a way of documenting-and processing-a singular time.

title: Democrats Face Test of Party Unity as They Plan Next Legislative Steps
summary: President Biden, Democratic leaders will have to balance competing demands from progressives and centrists on infrastructure bill. WASHINGTON-In the first months of President Biden's term, Democrats on Capitol Hill unified around his $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief proposal, quickly passing through Congress a package that closely resembled Mr. Biden's original plan and notching an early achievement.

title: AstraZeneca Warns Europe of Large Delivery Shortfall
summary: Drugmaker says it no longer expects to be able to import some 100 million doses in coming months. AstraZeneca PLC has warned European Union officials it no longer expects to supply the bloc with around 100 million Covid-19 shots it pledged to bring in from overseas in coming months, worsening a vaccine-supply crisis on the continent as cases rise again and governments consider new lockdown measures.

title: Short Seller Trains Sights on Lordstown, Prompting Share Slide
summary: Hindenburg report says startup misled investors on quality of preorders, readiness to start production; truck maker's CEO says report contains half-truths and lies. A new report by short seller Hindenburg Research took aim at electric-truck startup Lordstown Motors Corp. , saying the company misled investors about the strength of its truck preorders and the progress it is making toward putting its first model into production.

title: U.S. Wants India's Help on China, but There Are a Few Sticking Points
summary: The Biden administration wants to embed India in plans to compete with China but must smooth over disagreements on a Russian weapons system. The Biden administration is working to embed India in a network of countries in sharp competition with China, though they need to smooth over disagreements that include human rights and New Delhi's acquisition of a Russian defense system.

title: Can You Choose Which Covid-19 Vaccine You Get?
summary: With vaccines from Pfizer, Moderna and Johnson & Johnson authorized in the U.S., and others on the horizon, doctors explain whether-and when-you might have a choice. Is it possible to choose which Covid-19 vaccine you get?

title: The Journal Acrostic (Saturday, March 13)
It's Not TV, It's HBO With Ads
summary: AT&T to roll out ad-supported HBO Max version in June, forecasts up to 70 million HBO customers by end of 2021. AT&T Inc. said a long-planned version of its HBO Max streaming service supported by ads will launch in June, attaching commercials to a brand that for decades stood for premium content without interruption.

title: Texas Grid Operator Discussed Financing With Goldman as Energy Buyers Balk at Payment Shortfall
summary: Ercot discussed financing options with Goldman and others, while San Antonio's public utility sued to avoid liability for a growing market shortfall. The Texas grid operator has held talks with financial institutions including Goldman Sachs Group Inc. about potential financing options to address a more than $3 billion shortfall in electricity payments as some market participants balk at paying their share, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: U.S. Treasury Yields Climb Sharply
summary: Selling in government bonds puts end to several sessions of relative stability. Selling in U.S. government bonds picked up steam again Friday, propelling yields past recent highs and putting an end to several sessions of relative stability.

title: Ma Bell Juggles Its Bills
summary: AT&T promises to keep its crucial dividend while facing growing investment demands in 5G and streaming. If nothing else, AT&T 's past few years in show business seem to have taught it to keep the spotlight on the positive.

title: Name a Great Civilization Created by Progressive Leftists
summary: What exactly has the cancel mob ever built?. "To defeat woke tyrants, the rest of us must treat them like the monsters they are." That's the headline on a New York Post op-ed from University of Tennessee law professor Glenn Reynolds, who writes of contemporary cancel culture:

title: Virginia, Kansas Drop Out of Conference Tourneys After Positive Covid Tests
summary: The developments could render the teams ineligible for the March Madness tournament that begins next week. Duke ended its season Thursday under similar circumstances.. The fragile nature of staging March Madness during the pandemic came into clear focus on Friday when two Top 20 powerhouses-Virginia and Kansas-dropped out of their respective conference tournaments after members of their travel parties tested positive for Covid-19.

title: Microsoft Probes Whether Leak Fueled Global Hack
summary: Investigators seek to unravel how attack spread in week before software fix. Microsoft Corp. is investigating whether the hackers behind a world-wide cyberattack may have obtained sensitive information necessary to launch the attack from private disclosures it made with some of its security partners, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: AT&T, Verizon Vow to Boost Sales Before 5G Debt Comes Due
summary: Cellphone carriers count on plan upgrades, wireless broadband to justify spending on C-band spectrum licenses. Cellphone carriers that spent years promoting their blueprints for new fifth-generation wireless networks devoted the past week to explaining how they plan to pay for them.

title: Rubio Supports Amazon Workers' Push to Unionize in Alabama
summary: Republican senator adds rare GOP support to an organized-labor effort. WASHINGTON-Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) voiced his support for a union-organizing drive at an Amazon.com Inc. warehouse in Alabama, accusing the e-commerce giant of waging a culture war that hurts its workers and the economy.

title: Fed Weighs Whether to Extend Capital Relief for Big Banks
summary: Decision on pandemic-era policy could affect Treasury market at a time of rising bond yields. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve faces a decision in the coming days over whether to extend relief that temporarily loosened restrictions for the way big banks account for ultrasafe assets such as Treasury securities.

title: How to Write a Résumé and Choose the Best Format
summary: Most Popular News. You have just over seven seconds to make an impression with your résumé. That is the average time it took recruiters to make up their minds about candidates based on their résumés, according to a 2018 eye-tracking survey by the career site Ladders. Professional résumé writers say you could try shaking up your résumé format if you are struggling to get callbacks.

title: Why Authoritarian China Loves Woke U.S.
summary: You can't blame China for exploiting divisions and self-doubt in its primary competitor for global supremacy.. Regarding your editorial "The Woke Chinese Communist Party" (March 8): You can't blame China for exploiting divisions and self-doubt in its primary competitor for global supremacy. China was a half-century ahead of the U.S. in its Great Awokening and Cultural Revolution. Disastrous Communist Party policies led to a 1959 famine that resulted in 30 million deaths (4.5% of the population). That famine may have been a catalyst for a subsequent purge of people of privilege who were deemed responsible for China's systemic economic injustices. In the next few decades, China's Communist Party re-engineered the nation's culture, consolidated power in the state, rejected any elements of democracy and finally embraced aspects of capitalism that could exist in a command-and-control system. America's Progressive Awokening occurred in fits and starts until the 2020 pandemic opened the floodgates for the types of advances in "equity" (via redistribution) that China achieved in the 1960s and '70s.

title: Encryption Isn't Main Data-Security Threat
summary: The quantum internet or quantum key distribution (QKD) network wouldn't have prevented the recent SolarWinds hack.. Regarding David C. Gompert's "Effective Cybersecurity Needs Quantum Communication" (op-ed, March 8): The quantum internet or quantum key distribution (QKD) network wouldn't have prevented the recent SolarWinds hack or any of the other $6 trillion network hacks a year referenced, due to a failure of today's communications encryption.

title: How Israel Became the World Vaccine Leader
summary: The country made a deal with Pfizer: enough shots for everyone in exchange for data on the results.. More than 55% of Israelis over 16 have been fully vaccinated against Covid-19 in the 12 weeks since the first jab was administered to a wincing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on national TV. That's the world's best immunization rate and roughly four times the U.S. rate.

title: My Fellow Democrats, Let Earmarks Stay in the Dustbin of History
summary: House leaders are wrong to resurrect a process that invited corruption.. Every member of Congress owes it to the public to be a good steward of taxpayer dollars. Accordingly, a decade ago, Congress halted the process of "earmarking" legislation. It worked as you might imagine: Members of Congress would figuratively fold the corner of a page in a spending bill to mark the spot where they would insert funding for hand-picked projects to benefit their districts, not the entire country.

title: Artist Alice Neel Found Beauty in Her Neighborhood
summary: For half a century, the painter paid 'fierce, radical' attention to the streets and people of New York City. By the time fame came to Alice Neel (1900-84), she was a white-haired grandmother with a twinkling eye and a flair for unexpected candor, making her one of the rare artists to score repeat appearances on Johnny Carson's "Tonight Show." But that beguiling old-lady persona sprang from an intense, at times tumultuous life and a profound commitment to depicting, with unblinking honesty, the people and places of her time.

title: Year of Living Remotely: When 365 Days Went 'Poof' Into the Cloud
summary: One year ago today companies shut down workplaces; information technology hasn't been the same. One year ago today, many companies in the U.S. emptied offices, shut down workplaces and sent employees home, after the World Health Organization declared the novel coronavirus a pandemic and brought economies around the world to a grinding halt.

title: U.A.E. Giving Third Shot of Sinopharm Vaccine to Some
summary: Doctors say in some cases, Chinese shot isn't generating adequate antibody response. DUBAI-Health authorities in the United Arab Emirates have begun administering a third dose of the Sinopharm coronavirus vaccine to at least some residents, as doctors say the Chinese-made shots in some cases haven't generated enough protective antibodies.

title: Gov. Andrew Cuomo Faces Impeachment Inquiry. Here's What You Need to Know
summary: It is extraordinarily rare for the New York legislature to act to remove the governor. The New York Assembly has launched an impeachment investigation into Gov. Andrew Cuomo, probing his administration's handling of Covid-19 deaths in state nursing homes and allegations that the state's longtime Democratic leader behaved inappropriately toward female aides.

title: Here's What Post-Pandemic Fashion Looks Like
summary: Fall 2021's largely virtual fashion shows brought a surprising number of optimistic trends and noteworthy moments. Here, everything you need to know about what to wear next fall.. FASHION IS looking beyond the pandemic. No, the fall 2021 season didn't mean the return of thronged, star-studded shows in New York, London, Milan and Paris. Most of the collections were presented virtually via carefully edited films or streamed video in which models strode down runways in empty venues. But if crowds were absent, so, too, were pajama-inspired separates, cashmere hoodies, "elevated" sweatsuits or any other signs of the slovenly, WFH aesthetic so many of us have adopted over the past year. Instead, brands are pushing optimistic wares for our much-anticipated return to society.

title: When Intentions Don't Matter
summary: As recent controversies show, moral judgment requires asking if people deserve punishment for harms they inflict without meaning to. A journalist at the New Yorker was fired for exposing himself in a Zoom call; another lost his job at the New York Times for quoting a racial slur; an employee of the centrist Niskanen Center in Washington was fired for tweeting a joke about Mike Pence being lynched; an actress was removed from the cast of "The Mandalorian" for allegedly anti-Semitic posts on Instagram. In all of these cases, the accused parties denied malicious intent. Suppose they were telling the truth. Were they treated unjustly?

title: House Panel Weighs Moves to Rein in Big Tech, Aid Media
summary: News organizations could get an exemption from antitrust laws that would enable them to team up in negotiations with online platforms. Newspapers, TV stations and other news outlets that have seen their revenue siphoned away by online platforms could get an assist from Congress under legislation that a House panel took up Friday.

title: Covid-19 Slammed Canada's Nursing Homes. Now Deaths Are Way Down.
summary: Understaffed and rundown facilities were the epicenter of the pandemic, but a concerted vaccine push has reduced risk dramatically. OTTAWA-Canada's nursing homes were among the hardest hit in the world at the start of the Covid-19 pandemic. But now early data show that transmission and deaths from the virus are dropping sharply.

title: Nigeria Gunmen Abduct Students in Latest Mass Kidnapping
summary: Kidnappers separated girls from boys and only took the girls, former senator says. Gunmen kidnapped dozens of students from a college in northwestern Nigeria late Thursday, state officials said, the fourth mass abduction in as many months in a region that is suffering from a worsening security breakdown.

title: One Expert's Advice to Women: Take Charge of Your Financial Life
summary: Jennifer Barrett talks about what she learned from her 'aha' moment.. Taking charge of their own finances is crucial for women-especially as more of them must step out of the workforce to care for relatives. But, because of societal expectations, many women are never given the tools they need to manage their financial affairs-or see themselves as breadwinners.

title: How to Negotiate Salary for a New Job: The Do's and Don'ts
summary: Most Popular News. Salary negotiation is an art, but there are proven techniques you can use to get what you want. In addition to researching and crafting your pitch about why you are the most desirable candidate, experts say that creating a personal, empathic connection with your negotiator is also a good strategy.

title: Richard Branson Plans Next SPAC Deal, This Time for Virgin Orbit
summary: Branson's Virgin Group has played both sides of the SPAC craze and is now seeking a $3 billion valuation for its satellite-launch business. LONDON-Richard Branson's Virgin Orbit has hired bankers to help it go public this year through a special-purpose acquisition company, aiming for a valuation for the satellite launching startup of up to $3 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: How to Get Women to Start Talking About Personal Finance
summary: Claire Wasserman, founder of Ladies Get Paid, on what women on her platform want to know. Claire Wasserman is the founder of Ladies Get Paid, an online network for women to talk honestly about their careers and finances via digital workshops and Slack, a popular messaging platform. Ms. Wasserman sat down with Wall Street Journal personal-finance editor Bourree Lam to discuss how situations and priorities have changed as a result of the pandemic, and how women can start their own communities to talk about investing and personal finance.

title: ADM to Pay $45 Million to Settle Peanut Farmers' Price-Fixing Claims
summary: Growers had alleged collusion among top processors in civil complaint; two other processors, Birdsong and Olam, settled in 2020. Agricultural company Archer Daniels Midland Co. said it would pay $45 million to settle price-fixing allegations leveled at its peanut-processing division.

title: How Cathy Engelbert Steered the WNBA Through the Pandemic
summary: In her first full season as commissioner, she faced social upheaval and Covid-19-and made use of a 'Wubble'. Last March, Cathy Engelbert saw that her first full season as commissioner of the Women's National Basketball Association wouldn't go as planned. The pandemic promised to upend the league's draft and game schedule, but missing a season threatened to alienate sponsors and fans. "It would've been existential to be out of the sports landscape for 20 months," she says.

title: Iconoclasm's Nasty and Destructive Return
summary: Despite the wide-ranging call for diversity, is iconoclasm rearing its Medusa head?. Regarding Harold Holzer's "Monumental Error in the Making" (Masterpiece, March 6) on Daniel Chester French's statue of "The Republic": Despite the wide-ranging call for diversity, is iconoclasm rearing its Medusa head? The destruction of sculpture for political, ideological and theological reasons goes back to the pharaonic revisions of ancient Egypt to the purist-inspired devastations inflicted by the Taliban-not forgetting the toppled saints of the European Reformation or the overthrown images of generals, statesmen and kings during the French Revolution. And these acts of ruination are only for starters.

title: People Actually Look Forward to Going to the Dentist
summary: Resume Subscription. LONDON-Desperate for entertainment during the country's latest coronavirus lockdown, British people are turning to an unlikely next best thing: the dentist.

title: Europe Confronts Covid Rebound as Vaccine Hopes Recede
summary: Slow vaccinations, outpaced by virus variants, and indecision by EU governments are deepening the continent's gloom. The European Union's fight against Covid-19 is stuck in midwinter, even as spring and vaccinations spur hope of improvement in the U.S. and U.K.

title: No Shoes, No Mask, No Service? Businesses Now Write the Rules on Face Coverings
summary: With the end of the official mask mandate in Texas, each business owner must make their own rules. It's a preview of what's to come across the country in the months ahead.. Getting a beer at Hills & Dales Ice House in San Antonio doesn't require wearing a mask. But getting a coffee at the McDonald's franchise located a third-of-a-mile away still does. At Scout & Molly's women's wear boutique 20 minutes south, masks are recommended but not required. Heading to lunch for sushi at Piranha Izakaya next door, though, means putting one on until seated at the table.

title: Chicken Enchiladas Verdes
summary: These enchiladas verdes get a bracing taste of springtime from a topping of watercress salad dressed with lime. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: 'Lady Bird Johnson' Review: Behind the Smile
summary: Her charm was legendary, but White House watchers knew Lady Bird Johnson's power ran well below the surface.. A minor sport during the Johnson administration was watching Lady Bird Johnson's face when the president was rambling on, whether at a podium or a party. Her smiling gaze would be hardly different from the standard adoring-political-wife look, which she had perfected.

title: A Quick and Remarkably Fresh Recipe for Chicken Enchiladas
summary: These enchiladas verdes get a bracing taste of springtime from a topping of watercress salad dressed with lime. "MY MOTHER makes them, and my aunt. My grandmother made them," chef Diana Davila said of enchiladas verdes, her first Slow Food Fast recipe. Cloaked in a bright tomatillo salsa, corn tortillas wrap a filling of shredded chicken, sautéed onions and cotija cheese. Ms. Davila tops hers with a watercress salad and a dollop of sour cream.

title: Fiction: 'An I-Novel' Review
summary: A translation of Minae Mizumura's bilingual novel tries to match the original's Japanese-English tension.. The problem of translating Minae Mizumura's 1995 novel "Shishōsetsu From Left to Right" begins with the bilingual title. Shishōsetsu is a form of fictionalized autobiography that has long been popular in Japan. "From left to right" refers to the printed text. Ms. Mizumura, who has divided her life between her native Japan and the United States, liberally mixes English with Japanese; to accommodate the English words, therefore, she upended the usual vertical presentation of Japanese writing and published the book horizontally.

title: 'Terror to the Wicked' Review: Returning to the Sources
summary: Could a trial in 17th-century Plymouth provide justice after the killing of a Nipmuc trader?. Starting in 1636, New England was embroiled in a conflict that came to be known as the Pequot War. It was a war started and led by Native enemies of the Pequots, who like them were Algonquins-part of a large linguistic group of separate peoples stretching from southeastern Canada to the Carolinas. Before the war, the Pequots had established themselves as powerful middlemen in regional trade. Algonquins along the lower Connecticut River, where it empties into Long Island Sound, manufactured shells into wampum, beads that served as the region's currency. They sold it to Pequot traders, who sold it on to Native and Dutch customers in return for guns, ammunition, and other European goods imported through New Netherland. The conflict began after some wampum manufacturers attempted to bypass their Pequot middlemen. War broke out between the Pequots and the Dutch-and then spread, as the Narragansetts and Mohegans joined the anti-Pequot side and pulled their English allies onto that side as well.

title: 'The Enlightenment' Review: Daring to Feel
summary: The great thinkers of the time argued not for cold rationality, but for reason alloyed with sentiment.. David Hume, the pre-eminent Enlightenment philosopher, was born in Edinburgh in 1711. There he lived for many years, and there he died, perhaps the most famous Scot in history. It was thus international news last year when Edinburgh University-where Hume studied-stripped his name from a campus building. The move was demanded by a public petition that condemned Hume as a "man who championed white supremacy." While the search for a presentable honoree continues, the building will be known as "40 George Square," temporarily adding to the glory of King George III, whose views on race apparently command less attention.

title: Ant Group CEO Simon Hu Resigns
summary: The move comes amid heightened scrutiny over the Chinese financial-technology company; Chairman Eric Jing will take up CEO role. Ant Group Co. Chief Executive Simon Hu has resigned, the company said Friday, amid heightened scrutiny over the Chinese financial-technology behemoth.

title: Pharma Giants Get Their Pennies Pinched on Drug Pricing
summary: The vaunted ability of pharmaceutical companies to name their own price is vanishing as middlemen increasingly call the shots. The pharmaceutical industry's reputation as an omnipotent market force is increasingly out of date. Washington, D.C., hasn't yet caught on, but Mr. Market is in on the secret.

title: Covid-19 Rewrote the Rules of Shopping. What Is Next?
summary: Resume Subscription. Covid-19 changed the way we shop. The big question now is which of the new habits will stick once the pandemic recedes.

title: Spanish Police Seize Submarine Built to Carry Drugs
summary: 'Narco-sub' was discovered during an international police operation that led to the arrest of 52 people. Spanish police Friday said they had seized a 30-foot long narco-submarine that could carry 2.2 tons of narcotics, a sign of the lengths cartels are going to transport illegal drugs to the booming European market.

title: Mysteries: 'Wedding Station' Review
summary: In a prequel to the 'Station' series, John Russell is on the crime beat in Nazi-ruled Berlin.. English novelist David Downing pleased readers and impressed critics with his "Station" series featuring John Russell, an Anglo-American journalist in Berlin during and after World War II. The tenacious Russell, across six books published between 2007 and 2013, was forced to perform covert work for rival intelligence agencies while trying to follow his own moral compass as best he could.

title: 'A Fatal Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum' Review: Et tu, Brute?
summary: Never mind the Colosseum: the ancient Romans had an inventive way with murder.. A scene from HBO's series "Rome" came to mind as I read Emma Southon's study of Roman murder, "A Fatal Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum." In this scene, Atia, a wealthy noblewoman related to Julius Caesar, is entertaining two soldiers serving in Caesar's army. The conversation comes to an awkward pause, and Atia smooths things over by offering food to her guests: "More tench? A dormouse, perhaps?"

title: Five Best: Books on British Intelligence at Work
summary: Selected by John R. Ferris, the author, most recently, of 'Behind the Enigma.'. By Roger Hesketh (1999)

title: 'Stories With Pictures' Review: Windows on Dreamland
summary: A writer inspired by visual art takes readers into the space beyond the frame's edge.. Wooden blinds open onto a bright terrace latticed with cracked tiles. At the edge rises a stone balustrade whose posts cast shadows from the unseen sun. Beyond, two lazy clouds float in a sky of powder blue. We imagine, but can't glimpse, the calm sea below. This painting by Giuseppe Modica prefaces a short tale by Antonio Tabucchi, one of the 30 prose pieces attached to works by modern Italian and Portuguese artists in "Stories With Pictures." The story, "Bernardo Soares on Holiday," tells of a Lisbon accountant's trip on the fine Christmas Eve of 1934. He will travel not to "the golden domes of Samarkand," as he always wished, but just along the coast to Cascais. There, he plans to improve his writing, to refine his "palette of words" in order to evoke "a dawn and a sunset over the sea." Never mind the domes of Samarkand. For the "final Christmas" of a dying man, this modest craft will do.

title: 'Probable Impossibilities' Review: An Infinitely Curious Mind
summary: From the origins of thought to the cause of the big bang, Alan Lightman takes on brain teasers of all sizes.. Alan Lightman came to prominence in the 1990s with "Einstein's Dreams," a novel that drew on his expertise as a theoretical physicist and showed his gift for elegant prose. Since then, he has produced a steady stream of fiction and nonfiction that bridges science, philosophy and the humanities. His latest collection of essays, "Probable Impossibilities: Musings on Beginnings and Endings," maintains that syncretic spirit, tackling big questions like the origin of the universe and the nature of consciousness, always in an entertaining and easily digestible way.

title: Children's Books: 'The Age of Dinosaurs' Review
summary: The joys of fossil hunting come alive in books including a paleontologist's guide for young dinosaur fans.. As catnip is to cats, so are dinosaurs to children: a source of endless enthrallment. For readers ages 7-14, paleontologist Steve Brusatte offers a sparkling account of his trade and its discoveries in "The Age of Dinosaurs" (Quill Tree, 240 pages, $16.99), an adaptation of his 2018 bestseller, "The Rise and Fall of the Dinosaurs."

title: As a Window Opens, a Plea for Patience and Grace
summary: A sobering anniversary coincides with guarded optimism about the road ahead. This column is for people like me, who didn't write the Great American Novel during these past 12 months, or even 10 pages of a mediocre one, or attempt to build a castle from Popsicle sticks, or bother to teach the dog a word of conversational French. I'm assuming this is almost all of us, because those sorts of achievements are hard to pull off in any year, and this past year has been stressful and scattered, and on most days, it's felt like a sizable human accomplishment to pull on slacks and plod to the grocery store.

title: Novavax, Ulta Beauty, DocuSign, Citigroup: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures were mixed, with losses concentrated in the technology sector. Here's what we're watching before Friday's trading action gets underway.

title: Colgate Is Either the 8th Best Team or the 82nd. It Depends Who You Ask.
summary: Despite having a high NET rating due to fluky pandemic scheduling, the Raiders' only path to the NCAA Tournament is through winning the Patriot League. A quaint college town hidden in the deep woods of upstate New York is an unlikely place to find an elite Division I basketball team rated ahead of powerhouse programs like Virginia and Kansas. Yet in this pandemic-altered college basketball season, that's where tiny Colgate University finds itself-with one of the strangest March Madness resumes of 2021.

title: Lou Ottens Led Team That Invented Cassette
summary: The Dutch engineer, who has died at age 94, told his colleagues to design something more convenient and portable than reel-to-reel tapes. Lou Ottens was thinking about convenience and portability when he told his product development team at Philips to come up with something better than reel-to-reel tapes.

title: Editor in Chief Kristina O'Neill on WSJ. Magazine's Spring Men's Fashion Issue
summary: Our editor in chief on the selflessness of Premiere League star Marcus Rashford. Ending child hunger in the midst of a pandemic is not a task that typically falls to a 23-year-old footballer. But this month's cover star, Marcus Rashford, is not a typical British athlete. Raised in a working-class Manchester neighborhood, in a home where finances were stretched, he relied on school meals as a child. So the government's move to suspend a voucher program during lockdown, depriving struggling families of a much-needed resource, brought out the Manchester United forward's true colors. Rashford urged Prime Minister Boris Johnson to extend a $160 million voucher program, transforming himself into a powerful champion for the underprivileged.

title: Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Departure of three-term Democrat incumbent casts uncertainty onto the investigation of former President Donald Trump. Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr., whose office secured a conviction of Hollywood mogul Harvey Weinstein and is now investigating former President Donald Trump, said Friday he wouldn't seek a fourth term.

title: Pakistani Singer Faces Prosecution for Accusing Pop Star of Groping Her
summary: Meesha Shafi's accusation against Ali Zafar spurred #MeToo movement in conservative country. ISLAMABAD-Two years ago a Pakistani singer sent shock waves through the music industry and set off the country's most high-profile #MeToo debate when she accused a fellow pop star of groping her. Now she is being prosecuted on a criminal defamation charge and is facing possible prison time.

title: Antitrust Law and Why Congress Wants to Change It
summary: Democrats and Republicans are now considering the most significant changes to the law in decades. U.S. antitrust laws date back more than 130 years and affect every part of the economy. Democrats and Republicans are now considering the most significant changes in decades. Here's what you need to know about what might be coming:

title: China Regulator Fines Tencent, Baidu, Others Over Investment Deals
summary: The move serves as a reminder that authorities are intensifying scrutiny over China's powerful tech giants, antitrust experts say. China's antitrust regulator fined a dozen companies, including Tencent Holdings Ltd. and Baidu Inc., over a number of past investment deals, the latest sign of Beijing's broad crackdown on the internet sector.

title: Poshmark Looks Better on Sale
summary: The social e-commerce platform hasn't yet dazzled the way Etsy has, but maybe that's a good thing. Poshmark may not have had the fashionable start its investors had hoped for. It still seems like a keeper.

title: Covid-19 Travel Restrictions Loom Again for Colleges, Foreign Students
summary: Visa delays and embassy closures threaten to disrupt enrollment for schools' fall classes, putting billions of dollars in tuition and fees at risk. Nanxi Liu held out hope until August last year that she would make it to campus to begin her studies at Wellesley College in Massachusetts. But a ban imposed by the Trump administration on most travel from China during the pandemic made a flight to Boston difficult, and with U.S. embassies and consulates closed, most visa processing was at a standstill.

title: Covid-19 Crisis Has Left Americans' Wallets Fatter
summary: Unlike after past recessions, households and companies are in better shape as pandemic loosens grip-but wealth is unevenly distributed. One thing that has made the Covid-19 crisis a lot different from past recessions: At least in aggregate, the balance sheets of both households and businesses have weathered it well.

title: Black Rifle Coffee Seeks Like-Minded Aficionados
summary: The company says sales of its weapons-themed roasts and blends almost doubled in 2020. Black Rifle Coffee Co. says its AK-47 Espresso Blend "is here to conquer your taste buds." Its extra-dark Murdered Out roast "will fuel your midnight ops or your morning commute." Another of the six-year-old company's blends promises to "keep your freedom engine running."

title: Author Eckhart Tolle and Artist Tara Donovan on Desire
summary: WSJ. asks six luminaries to weigh in on a single topic. This month: Balance.. KAITLYN GREENIDGE

title: Contributors to WSJ. Magazine Spring Men's Fashion Issue
summary: What's it like to chat with Diane von Furstenberg or shoot in a classic Ford? Hear from the photographers, writers and stylists who made this issue.. THE WSJ. FivePhotographer Markn and stylist Chloe Grace-Press brought the season's best accessories on a road trip for WSJ.'s spring issues. "I wanted the images to feel classic and present," says Grace-Press, who styled the pieces against the backdrop of a Ford Galaxie's red interior on set in London. "But whenever I'm thinking of a road trip, I always wish I was in a car in Stephen Shore's book Uncommon Places," she says, referencing the photographer's 1982 classic. The mysterious images narrate a "love story or love triangle," Markn says. "Hence you have an image of the Dior sandals, and hanging from the rear mirror, a picture of the couple."

title: Shohei Ohtani Still Wants to Be a Two-Way Player
summary: The 2021 season may be the Angels star's last chance to prove he can pull off the difficult feat of both pitching and hitting in the major leagues. For two months in 2018, Shohei Ohtani made the unthinkable seem possible. He thrived simultaneously as a starting pitcher and a premier slugger for the Los Angeles Angels, a feat barely attempted-let alone accomplished-in a century.

title: The Green Investing Standard That Could Set the Global Bar
summary: Europe's new rules for institutional investors are woolly, but will be followed by sharper ones that may set the baseline for other countries. Wall Street needs to watch the European Union's early efforts to regulate what counts as sustainable investing. EU standards could easily end up as the global norm.

title: The New Trend in Home Gardens-Landscaping to Calm Anxiety
summary: As we enter the second spring of the pandemic, 'the quiet garden' offers a place to soothe jittery nerves. Here's how to achieve your kind of hush.. WHISPERING GRASSES, the plashing of a fountain, the hypnotizing crunch of gravel underfoot-Japanese priests have nurtured contemplative plots for centuries. Now housebound Americans seeking distraction and escape are establishing home gardens that evoke some of that Eastern horticulture wisdom.

title: Didn't Qualify for the Stimulus Check? Here's How You Might Change That.
summary: The difference between a full stimulus payment and no stimulus payment is as little as $10,000 of adjusted gross income. Derek Tharp (@DerekTharp) is an assistant professor of finance at the University of Southern Maine and the founder of Conscious Capital. He blogs at Kitces.com.

title: Nissan's Unlikely CEO Guides Car Maker in Post-Ghosn Era
summary: Makoto Uchida discusses confronting shareholder skepticism on his appointment and leading company through pandemic. Makoto Uchida was the dark horse in the race to be Nissan Motor Co. 's latest chief executive officer.

title: Covid-19 Aid Bill Stimulates Political Ads
summary: Democrats run ads in battleground states to note lack of Republican support for popular legislation. THE STIMULUS AD WARS BEGIN: The messaging battle over President Biden's stimulus package began before the ink dried, with Democrats eager to sell the package to voters more aggressively than they did for President Barack Obama's 2009 stimulus. Democrats are running digital ads in battleground states like Wisconsin and Florida to note the lack of Republican support for the popular legislation and urging voters to remember who put money in their pocket come November 2022.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Access: How Rural Transit Agencies Are Helping Get the Shots in Arms
summary: Resume Subscription. PORT TREVORTON, Pa.-On a recent overcast morning, Lou Ann Share waited for the bus in the kitchen of her family's yellow-sided house as her daughter made waffles for her 8-year-old twins.

title: New Covid-19 Jobless Benefits to Keep Stimulus Flowing Through Summer
summary: Some economists see payments helping workers and the economy, while others say the payments may keep people from seeking jobs as recovery ramps up. Enhanced unemployment benefits included in the $1.9 trillion pandemic-relief package signed on Thursday by President Biden could keep billions of dollars a week in stimulus flowing into the economy through the summer.

title: March Madness Still Leaves Most Schools in the Red
summary: College athletic departments run an average deficit of around $16 million, according to one sports economist. Each year, March Madness opens a fire hose of cash, as gamblers, advertisers and television networks try to get in on the action.

title: U.K. Sanctions Enforcer Releases Updated Penalties Guidance
summary: The guidance will apply to cases of possible violations starting in April. Updated guidance on monetary penalties by the United Kingdom's sanctions enforcer this week provides more clarification on self-reporting and suggests the agency may adopt a more aggressive enforcement approach, compliance observers said.

title: Companies Still Working on Libor Changeover
summary: Regulators press firms to drop borrowing benchmark, while many weigh its replacement or discuss timing, financial implications. Regulators are pressuring Wall Street to do away with the London interbank offered rate by year-end. Companies are still making the switch.

title: Korea's Big Economic Conundrum: Mo Money, Mo Problems
summary: Surging house prices and increasing debt have left the country in a balance-sheet trap that will be difficult to escape from. South Korea likely overtook Italy in gross national income per capita in 2020, a fact that made national news when announced by the Bank of Korea in January.

title: Bitcoin and Chip Makers Are Caught in a Bad Romance
summary: Crypto has proven a fickle suitor for chip makers in the past. Cryptocurrency miners love graphics cards and computer chips. Chip makers aren't returning the love.

summary: Holley, controlled by private-equity firm Sentinel Capital Partners, is combining with Empower Ltd.. Holley is merging with a special-purpose acquisition company in a deal that would value the aftermarket-auto-systems seller at about $1.55 billion, the companies said.

title: China All but Ends Hong Kong Democracy With 'Patriots Only' Rule
summary: National assembly backs barring candidates for city's legislature not endorsed by Beijing. HONG KONG-China drew the curtain on decades of adversarial politics in Hong Kong as the national legislature approved electoral changes that would put pro-Beijing loyalists firmly in charge of the city and squeeze opposition groups from elected office.

title: Cuomo Aides Called Former Staffers to Discredit Accuser
summary: Some recipients of the calls said that the outreach felt like attempts to intimidate them. In the days after New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo was first accused of sexual harassment by a former aide, the governor's office called at least six former employees either to find out if they had heard from the accuser or to glean information about her in conversations that some said they saw as attempts to intimidate them.

title: Biden Tells States to Make All Adults Eligible for Covid-19 Vaccine by May 1
summary: The president sets July 4 goal for small gatherings during his first prime-time address. WASHINGTON-President Biden pressed states to widen Covid-19 vaccine eligibility to all U.S. adults by May 1, calling for an all-hands effort to defeat the coronavirus to set the stage for small gatherings during Independence Day weekend.

title: National Guard's Capitol Presence After Riot to Cost $521 Million
summary: About 2,300 Guard members will remain in Washington as deployment is extended through most of May. The National Guard's monthslong deployment at the U.S. Capitol is projected to cost $521 million through May, the Defense Department said Thursday.

title: Vol. 34, No. 2: Immigration
summary: Most Popular News. There isn't one term that describes the millions of people who are in the U.S. but are neither citizens nor lawful permanent residents.

title: Ulta Beauty's Correction Is Overdue
summary: Despite retailer's obvious hold on beauty market, it made no sense for shares to be trading at such high levels. Transformation is the name of the game at Ulta Beauty . Turns out, investors don't take company-level transformation very kindly.

title: Biden, GOP to Sell Competing Visions of Covid Relief Bill
summary: Democrats will tout stimulus checks, other aid while Republicans will focus on the scale of spending. WASHINGTON-President Biden signed the $1.9 trillion coronavirus aid package into law Thursday, as he and Republican leaders in Congress began competing to shape voters' perceptions of Mr. Biden's first big legislative win and the early days of his presidency.

title: China's Baidu Aims to Raise $3 Billion in Hong Kong Share Sale
summary: Internet search provider intends to sell 95 million new shares. Baidu Inc., the operator of China's largest search engine, aims to raise about $3.03 billion from a Hong Kong share sale, joining a string of U.S.-traded peers in securing a secondary listing closer to home.

title: Read the Letter Amazon Sent to GOP Senators Over Its Book Policy
summary: Amazon said it has chosen not to sell books on its platforms that frame LGBTQ+ identities as mental illnesses. In a letter to Republican senators, Amazon . com Inc. responded to questions about why it recently removed a book about transgender issues that had been on sale on its platform for about three years.

title: Uber and Peers Face Defeat in Spanish Struggle Over Courier Employment
summary: The platforms would have to employ their workers and disclose details of algorithms affecting working conditions under new proposals. Uber Technologies Inc. and other digital platforms are facing a setback in their attempts to avoid the reclassification of workers as employees, after Spain's government finalized plans for the strictest regulatory reforms in Europe so far on delivery work.

title: Amazon Won't Sell Books Framing LGBTQ+ as Illnesses
summary: Company states policy in response to inquiry by several Republican senators over recent removal of book by conservative author. Amazon . com Inc. said it recently removed a three-year-old book about transgender issues from its platforms because it decided not to sell books that frame transgender and other sexual identities as mental illnesses.

title: N.Y. Gov. Andrew Cuomo Will Face Impeachment Investigation by New York State Lawmakers
summary: Judiciary committee would have authority to interview witnesses, subpoena documents. ALBANY, N. Y.-The New York State Assembly said on Thursday that it would start an impeachment investigation into Gov. Andrew Cuomo, vowing to look into allegations that he behaved inappropriately toward female aides and his administration's handling of Covid-19 deaths in state nursing homes.

title: Pentagon Brass Blast Fox Host for Disparaging Women in the Military
summary: Comments this week by Tucker Carlson widely panned by military commanders. WASHINGTON-Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin voiced "revulsion" and other top defense officials condemned a Fox News host over his comments this week deriding the Pentagon's efforts to retain and accommodate women in the armed forces.

title: GE Chief Gets Equity Valued at $100 Million
summary: Larry Culp forfeited his salary and cash bonus during pandemic, received new stock grant with revamped contract. Larry Culp voluntarily gave up his salary after Covid-19 struck and also declined his cash bonus, yet the General Electric Co. boss last year received a special stock award that at the end of 2020 was valued at more than $100 million.

title: Novavax's Covid-19 Vaccine Effective In U.K. Study
summary: But the vaccine didn't perform as well in a similar late-stage study in South Africa where an elusive coronavirus strain is circulating. Novavax Inc. released final results from clinical studies indicating its Covid-19 vaccine was effective against the coronavirus and a variant that emerged in the U.K., but less so against another variant in South Africa.

title: Coupang Shares Surge in Trading Debut
summary: SoftBank-backed e-commerce giant's IPO is the largest from a foreign company since Alibaba Group's. Shares of South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang Inc. rose 41% Thursday in the largest trading debut by dollars raised and valuation so far this year.

title: Why We Care About the Royal Family Feud
summary: The British monarchy has endured for more than a millennium, and the queen is a symbol of stability.. What just happened?
